newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan construction shares rise on sales outlook.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan construction shares rise on sales outlook.

text.p: Taiwan's construction shares rose strongly at mid-morning on Tuesday on expectations of strong April sales in the beleaguered property market, brokers said.
After 65 minutes, constructions had risen 2.25 percent to outperform the overall index, which was up 1.47 percent.
Pacific Construction climbed T$1.2 or 4.03 percent to T$31 and Pao-Ku Co rose the daily seven percent limit to T$85.5.

Brokers said construction firms, eyeing signs of a market recovery, had launched aggressive ad campaigns promoting planned residential buildings worth some T$200 billion, hoping to lure homebuyers into their sales rooms during the March 29-30 and April 4-6 holidays.
The United Daily News on Tuesday reported that real estate brokers enjoyed average sales growth of 40 percent in March, with brokers expecting even better performance in April.
"With the government's continuous bullish attitude toward the property market, the market is expected to recover gradually," said HSBC James Capel analyst Alex Chen.
Last week, the interior ministry said it was arranging T$61.477 billion in credits from the cabinet's Medium- and Long-term Funds to offer low-cost loans for first-time homebuyers.
The proposal was similar to a 1994-95 central bank scheme that offered some T$100 billion in low-cost loans to first-time homebuyers in a bid to boost the sluggish property market.
